===Etymology===
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*g-ram||indigo}}. Cognate with {{cog|lep|tr=ryom}}, {{cog|mro|charam}}, {{cog|bo|རམས||indigo}}, which Laufer (1916) considers to be a Chinese loan. {{och-l|藍}} was also borrowed as {{cog|tai-pro|*g.raːmᴬ}} (STEDT) and possibly {{cog|cbn|tr=khràam}}, Surin {{cog|km|tr=kraːm}}, and {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*ɟaːm||indigo}} (→ {{cog|vi|chàm}}). {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} considers this an areal word, possibly from {{w|Southeast Asia}}; confer {{cog|map-pro|*taRum||indigo plant and dye}} (> {{cog|ms|tarum}}) and {{cog|km|ត្រុំ}}.

===Etymology===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wp|lang=ja}}
{{wp|lang=ja|アイ (植物)}}
{{wp|Persicaria tinctoria}}
[[File:2016_1010_1119_dsc07615.jpg|thumb|250px|{{m|ja|藍|tr=ai}}: the '''{{vern|Japanese indigo}}''' or '''[[Chinese indigo]]''' plant, {{taxlink|Persicaria tinctoria|species}}.]]
{{wp|lang=ja|藍色}}
{{wp|Indigo}}
[[File:Indigo_plant_extract_sample.jpg|thumb|250px|{{m|ja|藍|tr=ai}}: the [[color]] '''[[indigo]]'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|あい}}

{{IPAchar|/awi/}} → *{{IPAchar|/aji/}} → {{IPAchar|/ai/}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=あい|-}}.

There are various theories regarding the ultimate derivation, all suggesting a relation to {{m|ja|青|tr=awo → ao||[[blue]]}}:
* May be an alteration from {{m|ja|青色||tr=awoiro → aoiro}}:
*: {{IPAfont|⟨awoiro<sub>2</sub>⟩}} → {{IPAchar|/awoirə/}} → {{IPAchar|/awɨrə/}} → {{IPAchar|/airo/}} → {{IPAchar|/ai/}}
* May be a fusion of {{m|ja|青|tr=awo → ao}} and {{m|ja|い|tr=i|pos=emphatic nominative particle}}<ref>Thomas Pellard (2013).  [https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01289288/document Ryukyuan perspectives on the proto-Japonic vowel system].  Frellesvig, Bjarke; Sells, Peter. Japanese/Korean Linguistics 20, CSLI Publications, pp.81–96, 2013.</ref>
*: *{{IPAchar|/awo i/}} → *{{IPAchar|/awɨ/}} → *{{IPAchar|/awi/}} → *{{IPAchar|/aji/}} → {{IPAchar|/ai/}}
* May be derived from a compound of {{compound|ja|sort=あい|青|tr1=awo → ao|居|tr2=wi → i|t2=[[there is]]}}, expressing the sense that the indigo plant ''contains'' the color blue:
*: {{IPAchar|/awowi/}} → *{{IPAchar|/awːɨ/}} → {{IPAchar|/awi/}} → *{{IPAchar|/aji/}} → {{IPAchar|/ai/}}

Given that many Old Japanese terms have been derived from adding an emphatic nominative particle {{ja-r|い}}, and the spelling was historically ''awi'', the second derivation seems likely.
